ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: We had one field trip to the lab. We should have gotten out more to look at diseases and insects and damaged trees. It was a cold spring, but we didn't get out once.
#9: This course would have benefited greatly from more time in the field looking at questions of forest pathology.#10: This is an extremely valuable course for the MF curriculum.

9) I know that there was a strong recommendation to find an entomologist when you become employed in a region and go out into the field with them in order to learn how to ID forest health issues in the field, but it also would have been very helpful for there to be a class trip to Yale Myers or another nearby forest.

#9: This class of all classes at FES NEEDS a lab and field trips! Forest health is a topic that involves the tangible. We should have a lab in which we can touch and observe fungi and insects. We should take trips around East Rock or the School Forest to observe diseased trees. Hearing about diseases and seeing pictures of diseased trees is inadequate.
We were promised multiple field trips but only got one. The one field trip we got was amazing though.
Ann's experience dealing with insects out West.

Professor Camp's responses to questions in class- she represents a wealth of knowledge.Talbot Trotter's guest lecture was excellent- we should be sure he can do that again next year, perhaps earlier in the term.

The guest lectures given by Mary Tyrrell and Talbot Trotter were an excellent addition to the overall curriculum of the course.The discussion around papers on climate change was enlightening, helped the class get to know one another, and enlivened the schedule.I really enjoyed writing the final paper for this course. I struggled with picking the topic because there were no less than three things I actually wanted to research more deeply after learning about them in the class. I wish that more FES courses had us write multiple times throughout the semester, and this course might be one that that would work well for with two shorter papers required--one just before or after spring break and a second at the end of the semester.
we can learn the main concept clearly
Presenting journal articles that we found ourselves. Quiz bowl.
I enjoyed the lectures. They were straight-forward and thorough and the prof. stayed on track.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Too many lectures that are outlines. Maybe adding case studies and having students develop strategies for dealing with forest health issues.

Field trips. It would be realy helpful to get out into the woods and look at some Armillaria, some adelgid, and so forth.Articles: We read a number of fantastic publications, but I feel that we did not talk about them enough.

this class should have had at least one field trip to the woods. seeing pathogens in the forest would have made the course much more useful. the organization of the class was not very intuitive to me. the lectures seemed to jump around a lot. spend less time talking about the concept of "what is forest health" and more time talking about specific pests and pathogens.

The lectures could be reorganized to have less overlap, which sometimes caused confusion. A more structured, repeated method for presenting diseases, pathogens, insects may also be helpful. The varying levels of detail sometimes caused confusion.The extremely opened ended questions on the midterm, while good questions, were hard to appropriately address in the time allotted for the exam. Getting us to write answers is valuable, but I think the class would appreciate questions are of moderate scope.Really, really would have appreciated a field trip to see some diseases/pathogens in the field! I think theremay have even been a stump on Edwards Street between Whitney and Propsect that had honey colored mushrooms that we could have assessed.
Needs field trips and labs.

I wish we had more opportunity to identify real life forest health issues. For example, I learned a lot of information on certain bark beetles, which is essentially useless since I am not working in areas where bark beetles is a problem. But I was hoping I'd be able to see a tree or stand of poor health and ID the problem and propose a solution. But after this class I dont think I can do that.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: TA didn't seem that available besides for one review session before the midterm and the second test.Ann could help elevate the TA's role in the class.

Professor Camp is always helpful and is available. She is responsive to email which is very much appreciated.Brea was the TA and was in a tough spot because she was the TA for a class that she had not taken before. She was very helpful organizing things, fixing digital glitches and such on v2, and responding to organizational questions such as timing of assignments. So, in this regard, she was very helpful. With the material, it was harder for her to be helpful because she was seeing much of the material for the first time as we were.
very little direction from either TA or professor about the final paper.
Excellent. They were both readily available by e-mail or in person.
Excellent. Super responsive and helpful.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I'm an MF and I thought this course would be helpful. It was ok.

This course is an amazing asset to the MF curriculum and to the FES curriculum in general.For me, it is indispensable and will be very helpful as I take professional examinations for forester certification.
the subject matter seems really important, however, the class could have been taught in a manner making it more pertinent to me future career.
This is an extremely helpful course for forestry and forest science students. I appreciated the emphasis on forest health issues in western US forests.
This course describes well a concern with my program, forestry.
It's a fundamental course in forestry.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to learn about forest health so that when I am working in the field I know what I am talking about. This course was very helpful in that regard. It would have been dramatically improved if we had spent more time in the field looking at forest health issues.
to learn more about pests and pathogens.
I felt it was important to be able to list this course of my resume because many of the jobs I intended to apply to had forest health related responsibilities/components.
The concept is helpful to my future work.
It was a requirement and I think it will benefit me in my career in forestry. I have an interest in tree disease identification.
Although I am not a forester, I wanted to learn about the various aspects of forest health because I have general interest in this topic.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes, for better and worse.

I had mixed expectations for this course and the course then exceeded them quite nicely.A few comments:1. Posting the lectures before they are given is very helpful.2. There were some points during the class where we were unclear as to what the next lecture was or what the assignments were. Professor Camp could be more clear and explicit about these and also be better at updating the syllabus in a timely fashion.3. Much of the material in the lectures is memorizable, as in- we should read it, learn it, and then come to class to talk about it. I think we spent to much time learning details in class and not enough time talking about how they fit together.4. The expectations on learning latin names were not clear. We should get a list at the beginning explaining what we needed to learn for the assessments.5. The content on the midterm was largely unexpected. I would have preferred a little more clarity as to what we would be asked to do. Ditto for the final- there was one section on the final where we were asked to identify pathogens as native or non-native. While this distinction was stressed throughout the year, I thought that this section of the exam was out of the blue and unfair.
not really.

It actually exceeded my expectations, particularly because as I applied for jobs the information I was learning I was able to reference in interviews. I pursued two job opportunities that were directly related to forest health issues we discussed in the class.
It did well.
No. I wish there had been labs and field trips. The lectures and class discussions were excellent, however.
As I stated in #13, I wish the course had given me more practical skills in assessing sick trees and IDing the problem.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes except that I wish we had spent more time in the field learning hands-on.
some things yes, others no.

I got more out of the course than I expected and the material I learned has already increased my understanding of issues brought up in another class. I also think that many of these insects, pathogens, and diseases we learned about in the class will be things I continue to encounter frequently after leaving FES.
I did.
I learned somewhat how to identify tree diseases, but I had expected field trips and labs for this course. They would have helped greatly.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Try to get discussions and activities going to break up the monotony of the powerpoint lectures.

1. Do the readings and then ask specific questions of Professor Camp.2. Ask for clarity of assignments and order of lectures.3. Learn all the common and latin names and where the pathogens come from.4. Study up on the Pacific Northwest- Dr. Camp references this region quite a bit and it is helpful to have a basic understanding of what the species are out there.

Do all of the readings--they greatly add to understanding of the material that's provided in the lectures.Be prepared for open ended questions on the midterm.Assemble a spreadsheet throughout the semester that allows you to keep track of the different diseases, insects, etc. that are taught. Will help you to avoid confusion when any are discussed in multiple lectures and will aid in your studying for the final exam.
Focusing on the main concept help the students learn this course.

Urge the instructor to take you on field trips. Work with a study group, because there is no way you can read all those assigned articles on your own. Divide the articles and summarize them amongst yourselves. Knowing the articles is important for the exams.
Ask to go on field trips.
